user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_for_upgrade:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_for_upgrade (MHD_UpgradeHandler upgrade_handler,
                                 void *upgrade_handler_cls)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

  if (NULL == upgrade_handler)
    return NULL; /* invalid request */
  response = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response));
  if (NULL == response)
    return NULL;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  if (! MHD_mutex_init_ (&response->mutex))
  {
    free (response);
    return NULL;
  }
#endif
  response->upgrade_handler = upgrade_handler;
  response->upgrade_handler_cls = upgrade_handler_cls;
  response->total_size = 0;
  response->reference_count = 1;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION,
                               "Upgrade"))
  {
    MHD_destroy_response (response);
    return NULL;
  }
  return response;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the fragments above because they reference identifiers/macros that are commonly implemented as compiler- or platform-specific extensions (e.g. storage-class macros like _MHD_EXTERN that often expand to __declspec or __attribute__ annotations, and library-wrapper names with trailing/leading underscores that may map to nonstandard runtime/ABI features). The rest of the code uses only standard C language constructs: function definition/parameters, pointer assignment, sizeof, NULL, if/return, free(), string literals, and standard preprocessor conditionals (defined(...)). No explicit compiler-specific keywords or known extension syntax (such as __attribute__, __declspec, asm, typeof, or inline assembly) appear elsewhere in the fragment, so those parts need not be investigated for Rule 1.2.
